rsbNotes.title: Ps 18
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 18 The psalm thanks the Lord for a great deliverance. The same psalm appears in 2 Sam. 22 with minor differences.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:title
rsbNotes.text: 18:title See Introduction: Author; Characteristics and Themes. The title unambiguously attributes this psalm to David.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:1
rsbNotes.text: 18:1 love. Not the usual Hebrew word for love, it emphasizes intimacy, expressing David’s personal devotion.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:2
rsbNotes.text: 18:2 rock. This term connotes protection. When David fled from Saul, he could find refuge in the caves and cliffs of the dry streambeds.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:4
rsbNotes.text:
18:4 cords of death. The tentacles of death rise up from Sheol, the underworld, to drag the psalmist down.

torrents of destruction. The powers of evil and death are frequently likened to an overwhelming flood (Is. 28:15, 17, 18; Matt. 16:18; Ps. 46:2 note; 69:1, 2 notes).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:6
rsbNotes.text: 18:6 From his temple. The place of God’s special presence. At the dedication of the temple Solomon indicated that this was the proper response to trouble (1 Kin. 8).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:7
rsbNotes.text:
18:7 the earth . . . rocked. When God reveals Himself as a warrior, nature convulses (Is. 24:4–13; Nah. 1:5).

mountains. The hills symbolize all that is firm and established in the world, but they shake before the might of God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:8
rsbNotes.text: 18:8 nostrils . . . mouth. The nostrils and mouth are standard figures of speech for anger (see text note). Smoke and fire often accompany a theophany (a visual self-revelation of God; Gen. 15:17; Ex. 19:18; Nah. 1:6).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:9
rsbNotes.text: 18:9 darkness was under his feet. God is pictured as coming with the storm clouds into battle. This portrayal is frequent in the Bible (Ps. 68:4; 104:3; Nah. 1:3; Dan. 7:13). In the New Testament, Christ is portrayed as coming in the clouds (Mark 13:26; Rev. 1:7).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:10
rsbNotes.text: 18:10 cherub. Angelic beings first mentioned in Gen. 3:24. Their role in Gen. 3 and their symbolic representation at key places in the tabernacle (Ex. 26:1, 31) indicate that they are guardians of God’s holiness (cf. Ezek. 1 and 10).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:13
rsbNotes.text: 18:13 voice. Thunder; cf. Ps. 29:3–9.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 18:15
rsbNotes.text:
18:15 were seen . . . laid bare. When God appears as a defender of His people, the waters representing chaos and evil shrink back. Compare 77:16–19 (reflecting on the Exodus from Egypt); Nah. 1:4; Rev. 21:1.

rebuke. God controls the chaotic waters of the sea (Ps. 106:9). Jesus shows Himself to be the Second Person of the Trinity by silencing the chaotic waters with His rebuke (Luke 8:22–25).
